SENT.plain: Sequence polymorphisms (SPs) can serve as genetic markers for quantitative polymerase chain reactions (qPCR) for chimerism analysis, providing a significantly higher sensitivity compared to short tandem repeat PCR
In this study, a panel of 29 selected markers was evaluated in 317 patients with leukemia and myelodysplastic syndrome, who received allogeneic stem cell transplantation
In total, 5415 posttransplantation samples were analyzed
Recipient genotype discrimination was possible in 96% with a mean number of 2.5 (1-7) informative markers per recipient/donor pair
Marker specific standard dilution series from volunteers' DNA served as standard for quantification of chimerism
Sensitivity of the method was < or =1 x 10-3 (0.1% of recipient cells) in 83.3% of the assays

By this method, it was possible to very accurately detect autologous signals in the range from 0% to 0.5% (95% confidence interval [CI] +/-0.2), from 0.5% to 1% (95% CI +/-0.4), from 1% to 2% (95% CI +/-0.6) and from 2% to 5% (95% CI +/-1.2)
Reproducibility of the quantified autologous signals was independent from the amount of DNA

This is the first report on a SP-based chimerism system allowing for the performance of chimerism analyses for virtually all patients with high sensitivity, excellent reproducibility, and precision of measurement
